Definition: The INSDC umbrella accession number of the BioProject to which the BioSample belongs.
Guidance: Required if submission is linked to an umbrella BioProject. An umbrella BioProject links together related BioProjects. A valid BioProject umbrella accession has prefix PRJN, PRJE or PRJD. Your laboratory can have one or many BioProjects.

Definition: The INSDC accession number of the BioProject(s) to which the BioSample belongs.
Guidance: Required if submission is linked to a BioProject. BioProjects are an organizing tool that links together raw sequence data, assemblies, and their associated metadata. A valid BioProject accession has prefix PRJN, PRJE or PRJD, e.g., PRJNA12345 and is created once at the beginning of a new sequencing project. Your laboratory can have one or many BioProjects.

Definition: The identifier assigned to a BioSample in INSDC archives.
Guidance: Store the accession returned from the BioSample submission.  NCBI BioSamples will have the prefix SAMN, while EBI BioSamples will have the prefix SAMEA.

Definition: The Sequence Read Archive (SRA) identifier linking raw read data, methodological metadata and quality control metrics submitted to the INSDC.
Guidance: Store the accession assigned to the submitted "run". NCBI-SRA accessions start with SRR, while EBI-ENA runs start with ENA.

Definition: The GenBank identifier assigned to the sequence in the INSDC archives.
Guidance: Store the accession returned from a GenBank submission (viral genome assembly).

Definition: The GISAID accession number assigned to the sequence.
Guidance: Store the accession returned from the GISAID submission.

Definition: The user-defined name for the sample.
Guidance:
Chose one of the following naming conventions for SARC-CoV-2 samples:
1) ICTV compliant name for INSDC submission: "SARS-CoV-2/host/location/isolate/date"
2) GISAID naming convention: "hCoV-19/location/isolate/date"

Definition: The name of the agency that collected the original sample.
Example: Public Health Agency of Canada; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Guidance: The name of the agency should be written out in full, (with minor exceptions) and be consistent across multiple submissions.

Definition: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sample.
Guidance: The email address can represent a specific individual or lab.

Definition: The mailing address of the agency submitting the sample.
Example: 655 Lab St, Vancouver, British Columbia, V5N 2A2, Canada
Guidance: The mailing address should be in the format: Street number and name, City, State/Province/Region, Country, Postal Code/Zip Code

Definition: The name of the agency that generated the sequence.
Example: Public Health Agency of Canada; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Guidance: The name of the agency should be written out in full, (with minor exceptions) and be consistent across multiple submissions.

Definition: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sequence.
Guidance: The email address can represent a specific individual or lab.

Definition: The mailing address of the agency submitting the sequence.
Example: 123 Sunnybrooke St, Toronto, Ontario, M4P 1L6, Canada
Guidance: The mailing address should be in the format: Street number and name, City, State/Province/Region, Country, Postal Code/Zip Code

Definition: The date on which the sample was collected.
Guidance: Sample collection date is critical for surveillance and many types of analyses. Required granularity includes year, month and day. If this date is considered identifiable information, it is acceptable to add "jitter" by adding or subtracting a calendar day (acceptable by GISAID). Alternatively, ”received date” may be used as a substitute. The date should be provided in ISO 8601 standard format "YYYY-MM-DD".

Definition: The date on which the sample was received.
Guidance: ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD", "YYYY-MM" or "YYYY".

Definition: Country of origin of the sample.
Guidance: Provide the country name from the picklist in the template

Definition: State/province/region of origin of the sample.
Guidance: Provide the state/province/region name from the GAZ geography ontology. Search for geography terms here: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/gaz

Definition: Taxonomic name of the organism.
Guidance: Use Severe acute respiratory coronavirus 2.

Definition: Identifier of the specific isolate.
Guidance:
Chose one of the following naming conventions for SARC-CoV-2 samples:
1) ICTV compliant name for INSDC submission: "SARS-CoV-2/host/location/isolate/date"
2) GISAID naming convention: "hCoV-19/location/isolate/date"

Definition: The reason that the sample was collected.
Guidance: Select a value from the picklist in the template.

Definition: A substance obtained from an anatomical part of an organism e.g. tissue, blood.
Guidance: Provide a descriptor if an anatomical material was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, use this look-up service to identify a standardized term: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/uberon. If not applicable, leave blank.

Definition: An anatomical part of an organism e.g. oropharynx.
Guidance: Provide a descriptor if an anatomical part was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, use this look-up service to identify a standardized term: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/uberon. If not applicable, leave blank.

Definition: A substance excreted/secreted from an organism e.g. feces, urine, sweat.
Guidance: Provide a descriptor if a body product was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, use this look-up service to identify a standardized term: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/uberon. If not applicable, leave blank.

Definition: A substance obtained from the natural or man-made environment e.g. soil, water, sewage, door handle, bed handrail, face mask.
Guidance: Provide a descriptor if an environmental material was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, use this look-up service to identify a standardized term: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/envo. If not applicable, leave blank.

Definition: An environmental location may describe a site in the natural or built environment e.g. hospital, wet market, bat cave.
Guidance: Provide a descriptor if an environmental site was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, use this look-up service to identify a standardized term: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/envo. If not applicable, leave blank.

Definition: The instrument or container used to collect the sample e.g. swab.
Guidance: Provide a descriptor if a collection device was used for sampling. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, use this look-up service to identify a standardized term: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/obi. If not applicable, leave blank.

Definition: The process used to collect the sample e.g. phlebotomy, necropsy.
Guidance: Provide a descriptor if a collection method was used for sampling. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, use this look-up service to identify a standardized term: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/obi. If not applicable, leave blank.

Definition: The name and version of a particular protocol used for sampling.
Guidance: Free text.

Definition: Any processing applied to the sample during or after receiving the sample.
Guidance: Critical for interpreting data. Select all the applicable processes from the pick list. If virus was passaged, include information in "lab host", "passage number", and "passage method" fields. If none of the processes in the pick list apply, put "not applicable".

Definition: Name and description of the laboratory host used to propagate the source organism or material from which the sample was obtained.
Guidance: Type of cell line used for propagation. Select a value form the pick list. If not passaged, put "not applicable".

Definition: Number of passages.
Guidance: Provide number of known passages. If not passaged, put "not applicable"

Definition: Description of how organism was passaged.
Guidance: Free text. Provide a very short description (<10 words). If not passaged, put "not applicable".

Definition: The biomaterial extracted from samples for the purpose of sequencing.
Guidance: Provide the biomaterial extracted from the picklist in the template.

Definition: The commonly used name of the host.
Guidance: Common name or scientific name are required if there was a host. Common name examples e.g. human, bat. Select a value form the pick list. If the sample was environmental, put "not applicable".

Definition: The taxonomic, or scientific name of the host.
Guidance: Common name or scientific name are required if there was a host. Scientific name examples e.g. Homo sapiens. Select a value from the pick list. If the sample was environmental, put "not applicable".

Definition: Health status of the host at the time of sample collection.
Guidance: Select a value from the pick list. If unknown, put "not provided".

Definition: Further details pertaining to the health or disease status of the host at time of collection.
Guidance: If known, select a descriptor from the pick list provided in the template.

Definition: The name of the disease experienced by the host.
Guidance: Select a value form the pick list. Provide "COVID-19" if the host tested positive for the disease. Put "not collected" if the information is unknown, or if the host (non-human) appears healthy. Note: "COVID-19" should still be provided if patient is asymptomatic.

Definition: Age of host at the time of sampling.
Guidance: Provide age in years. Age-binning is also acceptable. If not available, put "not provided".

Definition: The gender of the host at the time of sample collection.
Guidance: Select a value from the pick list. If not available, put "not provided".

Definition: The country of residence of the host.
Guidance: Provide the country name from the picklist in the template

Definition: A unique identifier by which each host can be referred to e.g. #131
Guidance: Should be a unique, user-defined identifier.

Definition: The date on which the symptoms began or were first noted.
Guidance: ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD", "YYYY-MM" or "YYYY"

Definition: A perceived change in function or sensation, (loss, disturbance or appearance) indicative of a disease, reported by a patient.
Guidance: Select all of the symptoms experienced by the host form the pick list.

Definition: The country where the host was likely exposed to the causative agent of the illness.
Guidance: Select the country name from pick list provided in the template.

Definition: Travel outside the country in last six months.
Example: Canada, Vancouver; USA, Seattle; Italy, Milan
Guidance: Specify the countries (and more granular locations is known) travelled in the last six months; can include multiple travels. Separate multiple travel events with a semicolon. Provide as free text.

Definition: Event leading to exposure.
Guidance: Select the exposure event from the pick list.

Definition: The user-specified identifier for the library prepared for sequencing.
Guidance: The library name should be unique, and can be an autogenerated ID from your LIMS, or modification of the isolate ID.

Definition: The model of the sequencing instrument used.
Guidance: Select the sequencing instrument form the pick list.

Definition: The name and version number of the sequencing protocol used.
Guidance: Free text. Provide the name and version of the sequencing protocol.

Definition: The name of the organization/authors of the protocol.
Guidance: Free text. Provide the name of the source of the protocol.

Definition: The manufacturer's kit number.
Guidance: Alphanumeric value.

Definition: The filename of the file containing amplicon PCR primer names and sequences.
Guidance: Important for documenting methods and the user should consider including this information in their INSDC submission, particularly if primers were designed in-house and not by a public consortium/network.

Definition: The names of the software and version number used for raw data processing such as removing barcodes, adapter trimming, filtering etc.
Guidance: Provide the software name followed by the version e.g. Trimmomatic 0.38, Porechop 0.2.3

Definition: The total number of sequenced base pairs divided by the expected number of base pairs in the genome.
Guidance: Provide the value as a fold of coverage.

Definition: Name and version of the assembly provided by the submitter.
Guidance: Provide the assembly name.

Definition: The name and version number of the assembler used.
Guidance: Provide the software name followed by the version e.g. Canu 2.0

Definition: The percentage of the reference genome covered by the sequenced data, to a prescribed depth.
Guidance: Provide value as a percent e.g. 95%.

Definition: The average number of reads representing a given nucleotide in the reconstructed sequence.
Guidance: Provide value as a fold of coverage e.g. 80x.

Definition: The user-specified filename of the r1 FASTQ file.
Guidance: Provide the r1 FASTQ filename.

Definition: The user-specified filename of the r2 FASTQ file.
Guidance: Provide the r2 FASTQ filename.

Definition: The user-specified filename of the FAST5 file.
Guidance: Provide the FAST5 filename.

Definition: The user-specified filename of the FASTA file.
Guidance: Provide the FASTA filename.

Definition: The number of total base pairs generated by the sequencing process.
Guidance: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

Definition: Size of the assembled genome described as the number of base pairs.
Guidance: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

Definition: The mean contig length is the count of base pairs in the average size contig of the sequence assembly.
Guidance: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

Definition: The minimum contig length needed to cover 50% of the genome.
Guidance: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

Definition: The number of N symbols present in the consensus fasta sequence, per 100kbp of sequence.
Guidance: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

Definition: A persistent, unique identifier of a genome database entry.
Guidance: Provide the accession number of the reference genome.

Definition: The identifier used to specify the consensus sequence.
Guidance: Provide the consensus sequence identifier.

Definition: The name and version number of the software used to produce the consensus sequence.
Guidance: Provide the software name followed by the version.

Definition: The user-specified filename of the consensus sequence.
Guidance: Provide the consensus sequence filename.

Definition: The filename of the file containing genome features such as gene names and corresponding CDS.
Guidance: Provide the filename of the annotation feature table.

Definition: The name and version number of the bioinformatics protocol used.
Guidance: Further details regarding the methods used to process raw data, and/or generate assemblies, and/or generate consensus sequences can be provided in an SOP or protocol. Provide the name and version number of the protocol.

Definition: The name of the gene used in the diagnostic RT-PCR test.
Guidance: Provide the full name of the gene used in the test. The gene symbol (short form of gene name) can also be provided. Standardized gene names and symbols can be found in the Gene Ontology using this look-up service: https://bit.ly/2Sq1LbI

Definition: The name and version number of the protocol used for diagnostic marker amplification.
Guidance: The name and version number of the protocol used for carrying out a diagnostic PCR test. This information can be compared to sequence data for evaluation of performance and quality control.

Definition: The Ct value result from a diagnostic SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR test.
Guidance: Provide the CT value of the sample from the diagnostic RT-PCR test.

Definition: The name of the gene used in the diagnostic RT-PCR test.
Guidance: Provide the full name of another gene used in an RT-PCR test. The gene symbol (short form of gene name) can also be provided. Standardized gene names and symbols can be found in the Gene Ontology using this look-up service: https://bit.ly/2Sq1LbI

Definition: The name and version number of the protocol used for diagnostic marker amplification.
Guidance: The name and version number of the protocol used for carrying out a second diagnostic PCR test. This information can be compared to sequence data for evaluation of performance and quality control.

Definition: The Ct value result from a diagnostic SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR test.
Guidance: Provide the CT value of the sample from the second diagnostic RT-PCR test.

Definition: Names of individuals contributing to the processes of sample collection, sequence generation, analysis, and data submission.
Example: Tejinder Singh, Fei Hu, Johnny Blogs
Guidance: Include the first and last names of all individuals that should be attributed, separated by a comma.
